I think this video is more harmful than informative. For example, the chart of damaging and non-damaging radiation: UV radiation is very obviously damaging in both a deterministic(sunburn) and a stochastic(skin cancer) sense. The atmosphere as well as the magnetic field of the earth protects us from the worst of it but for astronauts for example this is a very serious concern. Alpha radiation however cant even make it through the dead skin layer to make it to your skin and is only harmful if you ingest it.

Additionally, if you're going to do these interviews and have people say things that are clearly incorrect (I'm speaking specifically to the bit about cellphones and microwaves and their potential danger), It would be more intellectually responsible to correct these points in the video.

Also, and I admit this is splitting hairs, when you say that microwaves, UV rays, gamma rays, and x-rays (as opposed to alpha and beta particles) are "waves very similar to light", that is so because they are different energy level descriptions of light. Also, alpha and beta particles are also waves with a vastly differing DeBroglie wavelength.

This video is much below the standard of the rest of the channel and does more for aiding in the confusion around radiation than dispelling it.

Although i'm sure we would all like to say that we would know the right answer if he asked us, we probably wouldn't. When you're put on the spot it may be harder to remember things you learned many years ago than when you just got done watching a Youtube video on radiation. I'm sure right now you could list me a hundred facts about radiation, but in a mere month without thinking about the subject you will only remember half if not less of those facts, then, a couple of years later you will be able to count your facts about radiation on your hands. When you're put on the spot and asked about knowledge you only barely remember your brain tends to fill in the holes with information that might be incorrect but makes sense in your mind. Which is why so many of the answers given by the people he interviewed were completely incorrect. The truth is knowledge isn't really based on how many facts you know, it's based on how many thought connections you could make to those facts because the brain cannot remember facts just because you want it to, you need to stimulate your brain to recall memories by recognizing patterns and connections in certain situations.

What radiation does to you is correct, although where it comes from and how often it comes to you is WAY WRONG... it can harm cells... this radiation is called ionizing radiation. high frequency UV-rays, X-rays and Gamma-rays, alpha particles, and Beta particles are all ionizing, but they do not make up for 100% of radiation: ELECTROMAGNETIC RADIATION. electromagnetic radiation is light, from microwaves to radio-waves, infrared to visible light, UV, X-rays and Gamma rays to be specific. and as we all know, we emit infrared radiation, anything with heat does. It's also a misconception on how harmful it actually is... it CAN cause the effects described in the video, but the chances of this happening are usually way wrong: E.G. i have personally touched a radioactive material with my own fingers, unprotected. and things like microwaves, while possibly dangerous, don't harm your cells. they just make you warm/hot. it's also worth noting that radioactive materials are relatively rare, and you most likely won't encounter any dangerous ones in your lifetime, and if you do, you will most likely be protected.
If your being pedantic you could say that beta radiation can be described as a wave function. Although to be fair basically everything can be described as both a wave and a particle.

This is very well true, however not all radiation is bad. As from what I have larned from my classes, there are forms of radiation that cause heat (Infrared radiation). This type of radiation helps along with the three types of heat transfers: radiation (the movement of heat from a source), conduction (the trasfer of heat via contact of two objects), and convection (the transfer of heat using the circular movement of a fluid: lava, air, or water). It is true that radiation is harmful and damaging in quite a few ways but the two different types are negative in different ways.

For example: Ultraviolet (UV) rays are the main cause of sunburn and most skin cancers, however the ozone layer (where there is 2-3x the oxygen particals) can obsorb this radiation.

Infrared radiation is the main cause for heat. It passes through the layers of the atmosphere and hits the soil of Earth. It is then somewhat obsorbed by the soil and then reflected back into outer space.

Both types of radiation come directly from the sun in electromagnetic waves where it is then formed into visable and invisable light or radiation.

Therefore radiation is bad in a way, however it is not always the cause of cancer. People who say we can do without it are basically saying we could do without heat and sunlight.

I am sorry, but grouping them together into waves and particles, as well as damaging and non-damaging was scientifically not really acceptable.

Always take into account dosage and frequency of exposure, plus a biological predisposition such as already existing damage.

Like my biology teacher taught us: "Everything is dangerous (to a biological organism or even an organic molecule like DNA) if the dosage is high enough".

That assumption can easily by applied for radiation of any type. Dosage should always be included. If you expose someone to excessive dosages of microwaves you definitely will cause damage. So please do not overgeneralize.

Everyone everywhere on this planet is exposed to radiation; it just requires the correct measurement to detect it.

Damage is such a subjective term that it should be defined clearly.
Even the shortest exposure to the electro-magnetic spectrum of the sun on a cloudy day will have a very high probability (close to 100%) to cause some 'damage' to some cells in the body.

Is this damage permanent? Very probably not.
Is this damage dangerous? Very probably not.
Can this damage be repaired by the body? Very probably.
Will I become the Inedible Bulk if eat a pound Uranium 235? Very highly probably not, but most probably dead in a very short time.

Notice how often I use the term probable?
Yepp, exactly. Loads.

Why?
Because not every exposure to every type of radiation will instantly cause huge mucus or lymphal liquid filled boils to appear like those displayed in comics.

But almost everyone on this planet has experienced a sunburn sometime in their lifetime.
That definitely was damage (caused by a sufficently high dosage of UV).
So, yes, radiation can be damaging (and always will be to some degree or other).

But the long term effects vary significantly on so many factors that the term 'damage' is not exactly illuminating. For someone who relies on their beauty to sell female make-up products such effects as wrinkles, sun-burn, and freckles might be already damaging.
For others these might merely be a nuissance or not even that.

That's why I am quite disappointed by the actual information conveyed by this video.

I want to adress what you said about x-rays at the dentist or hospital (radiographers). "Significant dose", I think, is a poor choice of words, because oftentimes the significant is to the layman (the people you try to educate) used synonymously with "dangerous". 

An intraoral (dental) x-ray gives an effective radiation dosage of about 5 µSv (micro Sieverts), according to the Norwegian Radiation Protection Authority. This is equivalent to less than 1 day of normal, average backround radiation. They might be significant in terms of percentage of the total average radiation dosage a person recieves throughout a year, but this is something that should come across more explicitly. 

Furthermore, it is important to distinguish between various tissues and organs; Some tissues/organs are more sensitive to ionizing radiation than others. A Thorax X-ray gives an average effective dose of about 0,12 mSv, while an X-ray of the Colon gives an average dose of about 12,4 mSv. This is respectively equivalent to 14 days and 6 months of average backround radiation.

X-rays of the Thorax also uses  higher voltage and mAs because there are more dense tissues - bones - in the Thorax than in the Colon. This illustrates the importance of recognizing different types of tissues; The Colon is much more sensitive to radiation than the Thorax.

The issue with radiation is that what we worry about the most is low-level radiation. There are very few studies and even less of a widely-accepted conclusion on how much radiation you need to be exposed to before it becomes harmful. The biggest problem is with the main claim being that detrimental health effects happen later on after exposure to radiation. This is true with high-level radiation that doesn't outright kill you, but we simply don't know if it's true with low-level radiation. There's a huge lack of evidence, even with the studies on the populations exposed to Chernobyl's radiation, studies that have been going on for almost 30 years now. It's still all inconclusive.

And based on that lack of evidence, we have two major camps of belief when it comes to the effects of low-level radiation. The most vocal are the media, spokespeople, and conspiracy theorists that claim the effects will happen, definitely, some time in the future, or that the reason we haven't detected them is due to cover-ups. Maybe they're right. The other camp believes that the reason we aren't detecting them is simply because they are not happening at all, or if they are happening, they're buried under other, much more substantial causes of cancer. And maybe they're right. But keep in mind that for the time being, we simply do not have a conclusive answer.

And if you think you have an answer, I would love to read your peer-reviewed journal article on the subject.

All waves are nothing more than light, the difference is the wavelength. Shorter length, more energy. That's means that photons with shorter wavelength actually have easier to "go through things". For example, visible light can go through air, but not walls or skin. The shorter the wavelength are, the easier the light can get through things. This means violet light can get through things more easily than light, and UV-light can cause damage skin cells so badly that they become cancerous.

@skytz1337 For example, you gave the examples of mobile signals and microwave ovens.  Microwaves aren't particularly relevant here because they heat you up for a different reason.  Microwaves oscillate at the same frequency as the bonds in water molecules, which causes them to vibrate and heat up.  Yes, they do operate at higher outputs than phones, but then what about radio stations which output rays at over 40 killowatts?  They're not harmful because they don't interact with your body.

@skytz1337 I agree with your first point.  On the note of your second point, power is not a measurement of how damaging rays are to your body.  Yes, a very powerful laser pointed at your skin will probably burn you, but that's because you have pigments in your skin which absorb that energy level of light.  When you go down lower, there are many wavelengths to which you're nearly transparent.  At these wavelengths it doesn't matter how much of it is getting to your body, it's not harmful.
